title: Art project helps students understand life for refugees
text:
Reaching out from Ottawa to Afghanistan

Students at a high school in Ottawa found a unique way to connect with kids in Afghanistan recently: they drew their portraits.

The goal was to learn about children living in difficult conditions.

The students, who are part of the art club, were each given a photo of a child living in a refugee camp.

Then they sent them the portraits.

It’s coordinated through an American organization called the Memory Project.

Here are three students, the portraits they drew and their stories:

Shela Lamug

Shela Lamug, 17, immigrated to Canada from the Philippines six years ago.

Her passions are art and math.

She hopes to become an architect one day.

Shela Lamug, 17, said making her drawing made her more aware of what's happening in other countries. (Submitted by Mirella Frost)

“The Memory Project inspired me to become more aware of what is happening in other countries and to find a way to be able to help. I learned that gifts as simple as a drawing can make a child smile in the midst of war …. I was connected to a place I've never been to. It was, like, a way to connect with children across the world who are suffering.” - Shela Lamug

Nathan O’Hare

Nathan O’Hare, 17, is passionate about sports and art.

He hopes to become an elementary school teacher one day.

Drawing this child from a refugee camp made Nathan O’Hare, 17, realize that little things can make a big difference. (Submitted by Mirella Frost)

“The Memory Project … has helped me become more aware of those around us, and that the little things can make a big difference in a person’s life, no matter their circumstances.” - Nathan O’Hare

Basma Mohammed

Basma Mohammed, 17, is passionate about math and enjoys the outdoors.

She hopes to become an engineer one day.

Basma Mohammed, 17, said getting to draw a child from Afghanistan was a 'beautiful' experience. (Submitted by Mirella Frost)

“Being a part of the Memory Project was a beautiful experience, since I got to put a smile on a child’s face by simply drawing a portrait of them.” - Basma Mohammed

The students involved with the project belong to the art club at Saint Patrick’s High School in Ottawa. (Hallie Cotnam/CBC)

With files from CBC Ottawa
description: Students in Ottawa drew pictures of children at a refugee camp in Afghanistan.
